awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Student Loans and the Transition to Adulthood
awd_abstract_narration:
The majority of young adults now attend at least some college, and many take on substantial student debt in the process. More than two-thirds of college graduates now carry an average of around $30,000 in student debt when they finish their 4-year degrees. Recently, some experts and stakeholders have discussed various plans to reduce or forgive student loans, and some colleges have begun to implement programs to reduce loans for low-income students. This project examines college students’ and graduates’ experiences with debt. It examines how students with loans came to take on debt, examining prior experiences with parents, advisors, and peers. It examines student attitudes towards and knowledge about debt, as well as their experiences after college as they begin to pay off that debt. The project also compares their experiences to those who attended a university that implemented a new program to reduce or eliminate student debt, comparing the experiences of those with student loan debt to those who avoided debt either because of this program or without this program. Findings from the project will inform policies in higher education that aim to reduce student loan indebtedness, and provide input for families and political leaders concerned with the implications of student debt for young adults, their families and for United States society generally. 


Student loan debt has implications for students, their families and United States society more generally.  Building upon an ongoing longitudinal mixed-methods study, this project will involve conducting interviews with 24 college graduates with loans at two universities who were first interviewed right before their graduation in 2016, and have been interviewed yearly since then.  The project will interview this cohort in both 2020 and 2021. A new cohort of 48 seniors graduating in 2020 will be interviewed at a university that implemented a program to reduce student loans, with interviews right before and 1.5 years after graduation. The ongoing project also included surveys with 3,727 college students at two universities in 2017, as well as 173 graduating seniors from that survey again in 2018. Those graduating seniors will again be surveyed in 2020.  A new survey will be fielded at the university with the student loans program in 2020, with graduates of that university surveyed again in Fall 2021. Instrumental variable regression analyses will be combined with interview data to analyze selection into student loan debt, the different educational experiences of those with and without debt, and sentiments and knowledge about loan debt that may affect events later in young adulthood, including post-graduate experiences and outcomes. This project will help determine the impacts of student loan debt on the transition out of college and into young adulthood, and how student loan debt may represent a new ‘class divide’ among college graduates that produces differential outcomes later in the life course based on student loan debt status.  Findings will inform sociological theories of education, family formation, and transition to adulthood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how student loan debt and a program to reduce debt affected college students and graduates in a variety of realms, including family formation, health and mental health, dependence on parents, and impacts of the COVID pandemic.  We also examined which types of students were more likely to take on debt.

We collected and analyzed several rounds of interviews and survey data with two groups of college students and graduates, including 2016/2017 graduates in the first group, and 2020/2021 graduates in the second group. Data were collected at two regional public universities, and one of them implemented a program to reduce debt shortly after we first collected data; the interviews and surveys with 2020/21 graduates included those directly impacted by this program. We interviewed and surveyed graduates shortly before graduation and 1-6 times after graduation, including surveys and interviews both during and after the 2020-2023 student loan pause.

Our first paper, “Social Norms and Expectations about Student Loans and Family Formations” focused on undergraduates’ ideas about debt and expectations about how student loans would affect their futures. We found substantial numbers of students thought people with debt should delay marriage if they have debt to repay, and an even greater number thought those with debt should delay childbearing. Many would hesitate to marry a partner with debt, and participants reported a range of negative reactions to a theoretical person they were dating who had loan debt. Many students with debt reported they anticipated delaying marriage or childbearing because of their debt. This research uncovered some of the underlying mechanisms linking student loan debt to delayed family formation – namely social norms about debt, and the stigma of debt.

A second paper, “Student Loan Debt, Family Support, and Reciprocity in the Transition to Adulthood” examined support to and from family during college and after graduation, how this support differed by student loan presence, and how graduates felt about this family support and notions of adulthood. We found those with loans received less family support and were less likely to live with their parents in college, but were more likely to rely on family financial support after graduation. Those with loans also gave more money to their families both during and after college. Graduates with loans described complex feelings related to relying on families, with this help both hindering feelings of adulthood and helping them transition into a more secure future.

In a third paper, “Student Loans, Physical and Mental Health, and Health Care Use and Delay in College” we found that compared to students without loans, college students with loans reported worse self-rated health, mental health, more major medical problems, and were more likely to report delaying health, dental, and mental health care due to financial difficulty during college. Students with loans also report higher rates of reducing medication use to save money during college. These findings point to some of the non-financial costs of student loan debt; our ongoing research with these data—part of the subject of a book we are writing on this topic—finds differences persist after graduation.

A fourth publication, “Families, Relationships, and Paying for College” focuses on differences in family background, family structure (marital status and childbearing), and relationships with families, and how these are related to student loan debt, family support for college expenses, and other methods of paying for college. We found student loan debt is more common when students have parents who are unmarried, have debt themselves, and have less education, and when students report that they don’t like asking their parents for money. Those who live with their parents are less likely to take on debt, and those who are cohabiting but not married also have higher levels of debt. Older and Black students are also especially likely to have student loan debt.

Finally, we used our 2021 survey data to examine which students were more likely to move back home during the COVID pandemic, finding employment disruptions, dorm closures, romantic relationships, and reluctance to ask parents for money were related to moves home. These results are published in “Activating Family Safety Nets: Understanding Undergraduates’ Pandemic Housing Transitions.” Another paper under review found students with loans experienced worse pandemic effects.

The intellectual merit of this project is the research findings and publications described above, extending previous research on this topic in a number of areas.

The broader impacts of this project include mentoring and training in data analysis that developed the human capital of 1 undergraduate and 13 graduate students, 7 of whom co-authored conference presentations and 2 of whom were coauthors on published papers, with others coauthors on papers under review or in-progress. Research findings also have implications for how debt affects students and graduates in higher education, which has implications for broadening participation in the STEM workforce.
